Award.AwardTitle: Testing evolutionary hypotheses through large-scale behavioral simulations

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Along with the human brain, human cognition is a product of evolution. The complexities of human cognition, both individually and collectively, include sharing information, innovating, and developing complex technologies, institutions and norms. Why and how these aspects of human cognition and behavior came to be is a question that crosses many disciplines, including biology, psychology, linguistics, archaeology and anthropology. It is also an important one, as understanding how various aspects of human cognition and behavior came to be what they are could have implications for engineering artificially intelligent systems, enhancing and augmenting human capabilities, and improving upon societal conditions.

Traditionally, the evolution of human cognition has been investigated in either of two ways: 1) through computer simulations of possible evolutionary processes that took place over long periods of time and many generations, or 2) through laboratory experiments that examine the behavior of modern humans to test evolutionary hypotheses about aspects of human cognition. This research project develops an innovative third approach that combines the two existing approaches. In this approach, rather than needing to simulate hypothetical human cognitive processes on a computer, a real human being can complete a relevant task online. This allows for real human cognitive processes to be measured and then incorporated into the computer simulation of evolutionary processes. Each participant will perform a computerized task much like in many cognitive science experiments. To incorporate these real human data into computer simulations of evolutionary processes, each person's data will influence the next iteration of the computer simulation. Specifically, the task given to the next set of participants will be affected by the performance of the participants that preceded them. For example, the nature of the available information for a later set of participants might be altered based on the performance of the earlier set of participants. Across many sets of participants and corresponding iterations of the simulation, hypothetical evolutionary processes can be examined to better understand how genes and culture interacted over time and generations to produce present-day human cognitive capabilities and behaviors. The investigators will use crowdsourcing technology to recruit large numbers of participants, and will explore questions about the evolution of language, how complex learning processes evolved, and how genes and culture interact. The software developed to run these simulations will be distributed freely, making it possible for other researchers and educators to run similar simulations to address a wide range of questions about the evolution of human cognition. A version of the software will also be created for educational purposes to teach students about evolutionary processes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The evolution of the cognitive mechanisms underpinning human culture remains one of the largest questions in evolutionary biology and cognitive science. How and why we evolved to share information, discover innovations and develop complex technologies, institutions and norms is an active area of research in several disciplines including evolutionary biology, psychology, linguistics, archaeology and anthropology. Traditionally, the evolution of human cognition has been investigated through theoretical evolutionary simulations and small-scale behavioral experiments. This research project developed an innovative third approach: conducting large-scale evolutionary simulations with people.

As part of this project we developed a software platform that made it possible to recruit large numbers of human participants to take part in experiments that were structured in a way that allowed us to simulate cultural and biological evolution. Using the software, participants could be recruited from online crowdsourcing sites into "generations" of people who would perform tasks presented on a computer.  To simulate cultural evolution, the results produced by one person could be transmitted to one or more people in the next generation.  This allowed the solutions that people found to change across generations. To simulate biological evolution, a person could be assigned an artificial genome that influenced the task they were presented with. Their success on this task would determine how likely it would be that the same genome would be assigned to participants in the next generation. In this way, genomes that resulted in easier tasks would be selected for over time.

Using this approach we were able to conduct a series of experiments that explore key aspects of human cognition in the context of evolutionary processes. We successfully recruited large numbers of participants to take part in our experiments, with the typical experiment involving thousands of people. We were able to explore a classic phenomenon where learning influences the outcome of evolution, known as the Baldwin effect, in a human population for the first time.  Our results showed that the things that people find hardest to learn are most likely to become encoded in the genome, shedding light on long-standing questions about innateness and evolution in the context of language acquisition.  We also showed how learning and memory co-evolve, providing the first demonstration in a human population of a phenomenon that had been hypothesized in evolutionary biology. Finally, by looking at how the things that people remember change over many generations of cultural transmission, we were able to gain new insight into the structure of human visual memory. All of these results have been published in leading scientific journals.

The software that we developed has itself evolved into a platform that is now used by researchers at several universities, playing a role that has become increasingly important as more research labs begin to conduct online experiments. The software platform has led to new collaborations with social psychologists, economists, ecologists and sociologists, providing a tool for answering questions that arise in multiple scientific disciplines.

In addition to these scientific results, this project provided support for education and training of two graduate students and three postdoctoral researchers, several of whom now run their own research labs where they use and contribute to the further development of this software.
